awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Intelligent Autonomous Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Intelligent autonomous vehicles have tremendous potential impacts on aerospace, automotive, and manufacturing industries for improving operational performance, maintainability, and availability, as well as for assuring system safety and security and reducing operational cost.  This new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program, Undergraduate Research in Intelligent Autonomous Vehicles, at Wright State University (WSU) will operate as a gateway to attract more talented young minds to the emerging areas of intelligent autonomous vehicles and to develop technical and research skills they will need to be successful in their future graduate studies and careers in STEM. The program will target undergraduates from underrepresented groups and colleges with very limited research opportunities.  The program will focus on advancing knowledge in five crucial areas: vehicle health management, adaptation and learning methods, advanced navigation and sensor fusion, cyber security for connected vehicles, and human-vehicle interaction. 

Wright State University will host 10 undergraduate students over an 11-week summer program where they will be exposed to the cutting edge research of intelligent autonomous vehicles and engaged in the development of innovative solutions.  The goal of the REU program is to foster the technical, professional, and personal development of the participating undergraduates, helping them to realize their full potential in STEM. Additional distinctive features of the program include: 1) a unique three-tier mentorship program involving faculty members, advisors from industry and the Wright-Patterson Air Force Research Lab (AFRL), and graduate students; 2) strong engagement of students from underrepresented groups; 3) a professional skills development program that will help undergraduates acquire effective research and communications skills; and 4) a combination of basic research and applied research.

por.por_cntn:
This REU site in intelligent autonomous vehicles (IAV) at Wright State University has helped attract more talented young minds to the cutting-edge research of intelligent vehicles and to develop skills they will need to be successful in their future careers in STEM. A total of 31 undergraduate students from local and national colleges and universities participated in the program, including 13 students from underrepresented groups and 12 female students. The participants were exposed to the emerging fields of IAV research, including vehicle health management, adaptation and learning, navigation and sensor fusion, cyber security, and human-vehicle interaction. During the eleven-week summer program, undergraduate participants developed and applied their technical expertise in STEM to develop and implement solutions to their research projects, under the supervision of mentors involving faculty members of Wright State University, advisors from industry and the Wright-Patterson Air Force Research Lab, and graduate students. Various technical seminars and the field trip to GE Aviation in Cincinnati exposed students to broader area of IAV, including research challenges and industrial needs. Additionally, the undergraduates also participated in various activities for developing their professional skills for conducting independent research and disseminating research results, including skills for self-directed scientific learning, as well as effective presentation and writing skills for communicating technical concepts to the general public. The team projects also helped develop students' team-work spirit and professional ethnics.

The REU research projects focused on advancing the theoretical principles and applications of intelligent autonomous vehicles. Based on the research results obtained during the summer program, six research papers have been published in technical conferences/journals. When asked specifically about their overall REU Program's experience through a post-program survey, all participants agreed or strongly agreed that the REU experience prepared them to understand research, conduct research, and pursue future STEM career. Another objective of the program is to encourage students to pursue graduate studies through their REU achievements. According to a follow-up survey, approximately thirty percent of the undergraduate participants attended graduate school after completing their undergraduate studies.
